Award.AwardTitle: AF: Small: Geometric Algorithms for Constructing Road Networks from Trajectories

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this project is to develop geometric algorithms with quality and performance guarantees for constructing road networks from geo-referenced trajectory data. This is a new type of geometric reconstruction problem in which the task is to extract the underlying geometric structure sampled by a a set of noisy, movement-constrained trajectories. Different models for trajectories and for road networks will be investigated. Ideas from geometric shape matching, probabilistic modeling, and trajectory clustering will be applied to develop geometric algorithms with quality and performance guarantees that exploit the continuity of the input trajectories. Proof-of-concept implementations will be developed to test and validate the algorithms on real data.

Vast amounts of geo-referenced trajectory data are being collected due to the ubiquitous availability of positioning technologies such as the Global Positioning System (GPS). This project will help address the very timely challenge of analyzing this data. It will also provide novel algorithms for construction and maintenance of digital street maps, which are among the most valuable digital data resource in today's society. The results of this project will benefit a wealth of applications ranging from a variety of location-based services on street maps to the analysis of tracking data for hiking trail map generation or for studying social behavior in animals. Students will be tightly integrated into research projects, providing them with collaborative research experience.

Institution.Name: Tulane University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: ADMINISTRATORS OF THE TULANE EDUCATIONAL FUND, THE

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has provided theoretical foundations for constructing road networks from geo-referenced trajectory data and for comparing such road networks. Novel algorithms and quality guarantees, as well as implementations and experiments, have been developed. In addition to algorithms that construct road networks, novel distance measures for comparing and evaluating them have been introduced that combine geometric and topological features. These distance measures make quantitative evaluations of road networks and the algorithms that construct them possible for the first time.

The results of this research have been disseminated in a book as well as several research articles in theoretical as well as more applied venues. The website mapconstruction.org has been established in order to enable sharing of code and benchmarking data. Code for the map construction and map comparison algorithms that have been developed as part of this project have been made available on this website. Students have been tightly integrated throughout this research project.  The project has provided research and training opportunities for three PhD students, two postdoctoral scholars, and four undergraduate students.

There are many application areas that benefit from the outcomes of this project. This includes construction and maintenance of digital street maps, urban planning, analysis of animal movement behavior, and brain activity analysis.


Last Modified: 11/23/2016
Modified by: Carola Wenk
